<span class="art">28</span> Goldsmiths and coiners make great use of this rule,
when they propose to make, from three or more kinds of
metal, a mixture of a given value, as the following example
will show.

*Question 3.* A coiner has three kinds of silver, the first of 14 loth fineness, the second of 11 loth fineness,
the third of 9 loth fineness. Now he wishes to form a mixture of them
weighing 30 Marks, of 12 loth fineness: how many Marks of each sort must he take?

</blockquote>

If he take ğ‘¥ Marks of the first kind, ğ‘¦ Marks of the second,
and ğ‘§ Marks of the third, he will have ğ‘¥+ğ‘¦+ğ‘§=30,
which is the first equation.

Then, since a Mark of the first sort contains 14 Loths of
fine silver, the ğ‘¥ Marks of this sort will contain 14ğ‘¥ Loths of
such silver. Also, the ğ‘¦ Marks of the second sort will contain 11ğ‘¦ Loths,
and the ğ‘§ Marks of the third sort will contain 9ğ‘§ Loths of fine silver; so that the whole mass will
contain 14ğ‘¥+11ğ‘¦+9ğ‘§ Loths of fine silver.

As this mixture is to weigh 30 Marks, and each of these Marks must
contain 12 Loths of fine silver, it follows that the whole mass
will contain 360 Loths of fine silver; and thence results the
second equation, 

14x+11ğ‘¦+9ğ‘§=360.

If we now subtract from this equation nine
times the first, or 9ğ‘¥+9ğ‘¦+9ğ‘§=270, there remains 5ğ‘¥+2ğ‘¦=90,
an equation which must give the values of ğ‘¥ and ğ‘¦ in integer numbers;
and with regard to the value of ğ‘§, we may derive it from the first
equation ğ‘§=30-ğ‘¥-ğ‘¦. Now, the former equation gives 2y=90-5ğ‘¥, and
$$y=45-\dfrac{5x}{2}$$; therefore, if ğ‘¥=2ğ‘¢, we shall have

ğ‘¦=45-5ğ‘¢, and ğ‘§=3ğ‘¢-15;

which shows that ğ‘¢ must be greater than 4, and yet less than 10. Consequently,
the question admits of the following solutions:

$$
\begin{array}{lllllll}
\textrm{If}&u=&5&6&7&8&9\\ \hline
\textrm{Then}&x=&10&12&14&16&18\\
&y=&20&15&10&5&0\\
&z=&0&3&6&9&12
\end{array}
$$
